39264600.review:
Enjoyable story...Unfortunately it crashes quite a bit at the worst times which is easily the worst part about this game.  I've had to completely redo boss fights which can be pretty annoying since they are sometimes kind of long.  Best advice, save as often as possible.  I also got a black screen during certain cutscenes.  The scene still advanced and went back to the gameplay after it was done, but unfortunately I missed out on what I was supposed to be seeing.  Reloading seemed to fix this, and it didn't happen all that often.

I like the story, but some of the characters kind of annoy me once in awhile.  Elena namely.  

Combat is kind of cool, even by todays standards.  Turn based with a little bit of a twist.  You have your character perform an action, then he runs up to the enemy to make the attack (enemies do the same to you).  This adds a layer of strategy because if you perform your action at the right time, you can counter attack for extra damage, or even block at the last second if you won't be able to make it for the counter attack window.  You can also interrupt enemy actions as well.

Spells come in the form of "stones"  kind of like materia in FF7.  Equip the stone you want to cast the spells you want that character to have.  These spells can also be upgraded as well as each characters skills.

It took me about 40 hours to complete which was normal for rpgs back then.  I didn't run into any side quests or end game content, so 35-40 hours is probably pretty normal.  So it's up to you to decide if the $20 price tag is worth it.  It's definitely not a lot, but you might still want to wait for a sale.

I'd probably give this an 8 out of 10 because the story picks up in the last quarter of the game.

正统日式RPG的范本。虽然采用的是迷宫-城镇-迷宫循环往复的游戏模式，而且没有什么分支和支线，但是由于十分讨巧的故事和角色设定（比起两位女主，个人更加喜爱Tio），35个小时玩下来并不会让人感觉单调。部分得益于原作领先同时代的画质（顺便给DC烧个香）和战斗系统，本作移植到PC端后并没有给人过分古旧的感觉。

Even with the Square Enix name behind it, this game never got the recognition it deserved. It was first released on the Dreamcast. The more accessible PS2 port was abysmal, known for crashing, and the PC port just wasn't well-received by PC gamers at the time. I was lucky enough to play the Dreamcast version, and I loved it. It was one of the first RPGs I ever completed (along with the similarly fantastic and overlooked Skies of Arcadia).

How does this hold up 17 years later? Surprisingly well!

I'll start with my main criticisms.

The first thing it throws you into is an awful, dizzying camera that moves too fast when turned and zooms weirdly whenever you stop moving. The first short area of the game is the worst about this. Make it out of the first village, and you can take off your anti-seasickness wristbands.

For some reason, even in this shiny cleaned-up version of the game, where glitched spells have been fixed, nobody bothered to fix the mis-translated spell descriptions, so for your convenience, here is THE TRUTH: Freeze! Does not drop Action, it drops Movement. Cold does not drop Movement, it drops Action. Stram only negatively affects attack, not defense. 

The writing quality is all over the place. I feel like the beginning of the game is really solid, and it sort of starts to come apart at the seams as it goes along. NPC dialogue didn't really get a dust-up, so sometimes NPCs will mention plot points you haven't even gotten to in the main story yet. Ryudo can go from casual speech to some sort of weird formal tone at the drop of a hat. The voice acting is impressive, especially for its time, but can get pretty corny. That said, I turned on the Japanese VA for the first half of the game, and it's cool to hear it, but I ended up really missing the voices I was familiar with, so I switched back. 

I love this game's story and characters, as goofy and melodramatic as they can be. I don't want to spoil too much for you, but expect a lot of talk about THE HEART and FRIENDSHIP and LOVE, to the point that it sounds like a parody of bad JRPG dialogue. Regardless, it is the earnest, loveable kind of cheesiness. 

The BEST part of Grandia II is its battle system. It's not a traditional turn-based system; it's more of a modified ATB. When one of your characters reaches Command on the gauge, time freezes so you can choose what you want them to do. This gives you a lot of freedom. You could block or evade incoming attacks. Critical strikes (which you can do at any time) and certain super moves allow you to cancel enemy moves and send their icons flying back to the end of the queue. Some spells can affect how quickly you reach your turns. Distance and position are also factored into battle. AOE and line attacks are a staple. The more you upgrade your Mana Eggs and your super moves, the faster your characters will execute them in battle.

I'll never understand why we didn't see more RPGs with battle systems in this vein-- it's infinitely more engaging than just taking turns, and it gives you a lot of strategic opportunities. Battles feel good to play. Unfortunately, at the time, it was stylish for RPGs to have really, really long animations for attacks and spells. Though the unnessecary length of spell/move animations can get a little old, for the most part, fights are punchy and exciting. If you want to challenge yourself a bit (since this game is pretty cheesable if you know what you're doing), see how many fights you can end without getting any of your party members hit.

If you're craving something with a really classic RPG feel, give this one a shot. It is flawed, but I think it's definitely worth the experience. It's too bad they never made any more Grandia games.

33756797.review:
Grandia II - Anniversary Edition é uma edição do famoso game da saga Grandia que foi criada nos primórdios do Playstation One e saiu sua versão remasterizada para a Steam, sendo recriada pela Square Enix (a mesma de Final Fantasy).

A estória de Grandia II é totalmente diferente de Grandia, inclusive com personagens diferentes, mas a essência continua parecida. Ryudo, o protagonista mestre na arte da espada é um mercenário que ganhava a vida com escoltas e contratações de serviços, até que conheceu Elena, uma "irmã" que foi criada em uma Igreja de certa divindade no mundo de Grandia. No início, a missão de Ryudo era escoltar Elena para que esta chegasse em outro vilarejo para dar maiores instruções a este povo sobre a ameaça do demônio Valmar que estaria sendo ressuscitado aos poucos e que a renascença dele traria o caos no planeta.

Bom, como em qualquer JRPG, a estória vai se desenrolando durante a jogatina, sendo que o jogador deve ir a diversos mapas e aumentando o nível de seus personagens quando há várias cenas de luta, aliando também a aquisições de novas armas, vestimentas, acessórios e magias, aumentando os níveis de HP (life), MP (magia) e SP (especiais). Este último é para os golpes especiais de cada personagem (equivale ao "limit break" de Final Fantasy VII). O jogo em si não é difícil de pegar as manhas e é relativamente fácil enfrentar os bosses, mas precisa ter um certo conhecimento e treinamento para aprender a utilizar corretamente cada tipo de magia, especiais e armamentos para não ser surpreendido. Além das magias, o jogador adquire itens que podem substituir os poderes das magias quando estas estão indisponíveis, como todo JRPG deve ser.

Graficamente, Grandia II foi remasterizado, mas de forma bem sutil a ponto de ainda ter gráficos de PS2, por isso, não é o destaque do jogo, apesar de várias cutscenes em CG. Personagens em formato "chibi" é o tradicional desse tipo de game, portanto, nada de novidade. No som também não há melhorias significativas, mas a trilha sonora continua ótima, junto de cenas onde há falas em áudio (em inglês ou japonês, cabe o jogador escolher no menu). Nem preciso dizer que as falas em japonês dão um banho em relação Às falas em inglês, por isso, desde sempre jogue com áudio em japonês com letreiros em inglês (em praticamente 100% dos casos quando há esse tipo de escolha em games)! O desfio de Grandia II não é dos mais difíceis e o jogador consegue terminar sem precisar usar a grande maioria dos itens de das magias, mas conseguirá terminar mais facilmente se souber as fraquezas dos inimigos usando as magias e os itens corretos (não apenas ficar em "heal" quando o HP do personagem está baixo ou usando um "esuna" para curar toda hora status negativo). O grande destaque é a estória, mesmo ela sendo meio clichê. Os personagens são carismáticos e envolventes.  Agora se você me perguntar, qual foi melhor: Grandia ou Grandia 2? Na minha opinião, o antecessor ainda é melhor, pois mesmo tendo gráficos de gração anterior a do Grandia II, os personagens de Grandia I achei ainda mais carismáticos que os de Grandia II. Mas nem por isso, seu sucessor não é ruim, pelo contrário, continua bom.

Grandia II foi um grande sucesso para sua época e seu relançamento para Steam pode matar as saudades de um estilo tradicional de RPG que era gostoso de se jogar da época. Recomendado para os que curtem RPGS de vários tipos.

Having missed out on playing Grandia 2 originally, I jumped at the chance to do so on my PC. I have played Grandia way back when, and although the sequel does not share any of the characters or the world, the art style and vibrant characters and environment do seem familiar - in a good way! 

So, what is it about this game that makes it so that months after putting it down, it is a game I look back on with misty eyes and a headful of fun memories and wish there were more out there like it? 

[h1]Let's see now...[/h1] 

You play as Ryudo, a bounty-hunter of a sell sword who will lend his blade for some coin (or free food, at times!). Now this guy, for me, he single-handedly raised the game from a pleasant experience to a hilarious one! Unlike your typical helpful hero, Ryudo always had a sarcastic remark waiting to be sprung and was more than happy to tell you what was on his mind! Whilst, this could have created a rather annoyingly obnoxious character, it did the opposite. I appreciated the honesty in his amusing quips, he did not care if you were the Pope or the princess, he was going to tell you exactly what he thought of you! He seemed to have little patience for children too, but let's be honest, who does? I'll come to some quotes from him a little later, it is best seen for yourself! 

A few other things worth mentioning: 

[h1]The visuals[/h1]

It was easy on the eyes. Unlike some games I have played, whereby the blandness and greyscale worlds are literally seeping out my soul, Grandia 2 was vibrant, it was alive, it had locations where I was happy to prance about and look for things to kill. Granted, I always spent a little too long in the towns looking for people to annoy/houses to loot! So many pots to overturn!

[h1]The cast[/h1]

The characters were interesting, well written and brought to life with some great voice acting. The ever- changing expressions on their dialogue reels were a nice touch too, Ryudo could go from looking very annoyed, to being dumbfounded, with the expressive imagery. A nice little touch taken from the original game.

[h1]The combat[/h1]

The combat, in my opinion is what most players will remember the game for. It does away with the random monster encounters, with the enemies visible in the world around you, giving you the option to sneak behind them for a surprise attack or... sneak by them entirely if you were not feeling the need to bloody your sword! When you are wanting to battle, you will have the ability to move your characters around the battlefield, set up attacks and abilities in such a way that you are able to interrupt or counter-attack foes – this is incredibly satisfying! To control the combat in such a way, meant you were almost always able to render some enemies useless! There is also no end of abilities, magic and special moves that you can unlock through experience gain.

[h1]Summarisations![/h1]

In short, I cannot recommend Grandia 2 highly enough. It has everything I love in a game and then some. This game just just as good as I remember it. 

[h1] The Battle System  [/h1]
The battle system ensures that even easy fights are engaging. Often times there are 6 or more enemies to face in a single fight, and the starting "turn" order is randomized, which means that the same fight can play out in many different ways. While you're not really threatened with death outside of a boss battle, the distance between save points can be kind of long. This means you don't want enemy damage to add up, so you'll want to end fights as quickly and safely as possible. This means you'll make interesting decisions between canceling the opponents turn or spending MP or SP to use more powerful attacks. When you time your cancel after the opponent has chosen their next attack, but before the attack comes out, you cancel the entire attack completely, which is increadibly satisfying. 


[h1] The Story  [/h1] (spoilers, obviously)
Some people might find the plot to be sort of generic for a JRPG, but the characters are memorable and feel grounded and realistic. Without spoiling much, it has a similar vibe to Super Mario RPG, as a "roadtrip plot" where you meet interesting characters and learn about the world along the way to a distant destination. The best part, in my opinion, is when your characters sit around a dinner table and somewhat-organically discuss their thoughts on recent events. This gives the characters a chance to "respond" to the plot in a way so many Japanese games/anime lack (outside of mid-battle sermons and internal monologues) and it builds a believable friendship among the cast.

[h1] The Port  [/h1]
Works good. Some UI elements like the Save menu that's been adapted for PC look a bit simple, but function perfectly. The textures are clear, and despite it's age, the stylized and colorful art design has aged gracefully, for the most part. The addition of a "hard mode" is greatly appreciated, though it's still not very challenging outside of boss battles. I haven't done any A/B comparisons to see what's changed in the Hard Mode, if anyone knows, please let me know. All-in-all If you are going to buy this game, this is the version I recommend buying.

Grandia 2 is a little gem from back in the Dreamcast days. It was originally released for the Dreamcast and then ported to the Playstation 2. The DC version was better, as the PS2 had some really bad slow down. But none the less, it is a great JRPG.

The sequel to the original Grandia, this time the story follows Ryudo, a Geohound (Mercenary). Ryudo is hired to escort a young priestess, Elena, to the holy capitol, however, adventure ensues. The story is pretty good, with plenty of interesting characters as well as character development over its 50+ hour game length.

This being an RPG and all, the battle system is quite unique. Enemies are seen on the field before being encountered, and thus can be avoided. Once a battle starts we're treated to the action bar. The action bar, in the bottom right corner of the screen, shows the player characters as well as the enemies. When the head icon gets to "Act" that character or enemy can.....act. The player is given the choice of combo, critical, items, magic or special attacks. Each character is given unique special attacks and can equip an item called a "mana egg" to use magic. Special attacks and magic can be used in different ways, they can hit a line in front of the charcter, a circle around them or an enemy, all or one enemy. The most interesting aspect of the combat is the ability to "cancel" an enemies move. Using the critical option or a special move with the "cancel" effect, the player can stop an enemy from using a special attack or magic. This causes battles to be more strategic, if you see an enemy beginning a powerful spell, cancel it!

The player has levels, as is typical of an RPG, but gets special and magic coins. These coins can be used to increase and unlock special attacks and magic as well as power them up. The player may also equip special books onto the party, increases certain statistics (IE Strength, Intelligence etc.) These may also be powered up with special coins.

The story is pretty good, with fully voiced cutscenes and humorous dialogue to boot. The characters grow plenty during the story, and its impressive to watch. There are also a few twists that I will not reveal. However, the game is rather linear, with very little in the way of sidequests or additional content. Still, that shouldn't stop anyone from playing this game.

A classic sort of JRPG, and from a forgotten series, Grandia 2 has some faults. The graphics have not aged well, even though its been updated, it still doesn't look great. However, a lot of the magic abilites use anime-style animations, so they still look great. The lack of exploration and the linearity reduce it's overall replay value. While there are interesting characters, the party only ever consists of 4 at a time, you never get to select your party members.

Anyone whose anyone can probably remember Grandia, the lost little RPG. This series has been lost for a while, and it's great to see that Square placed it onto Steam for more people to actually play it. Hopefully this means we can get some more Grandia games. Grandia was a great series, the battle system is unique and interesting, and the character development overall the series is spectacular. So do yourself a favor, spend the $20, you won't be disappointed.

From a gameplay standpoint, Grandia 2 is one of the best JRPGs I've played. In a way, this game is a bit similar to Final Fantasy 5: the battles and gameplay mechanics are the star of the show while the story more or less takes a backseat (though Grandia 2's story isn't as painfully generic as FF5's).

This game takes real-time combat based on a single time bar everyone shares, and makes it turn-based. Attacks and spells (mostly) have a charging time, and you can cancel any enemy's attack with a critical hit at the right time. Other attacks and spells will stagger the enemy's time bar/animation, so battles have a nice interactive dynamic where you can affect what the enemies are able to do, and they don't just churn out spells all the time regardless of what you do.

I can't say anything else other than the gameplay is really satisfying. More JRPGs should do this, as it's a great marriage of turn-based combat on a real-time field, that doesn't compromise by forcing you to play only one character while the AI controls the rest of your party, or other things I've come to despise in "modern" JRPGs.

There are some downsides like not being able to skip spell animations and reliance on AOE damage later on, but overall, Grandia 2 is the most fun I've had with a JRPG in quite a while. Also, it's nice to get a chance to play a classic Dreamcast game, as I never had a chance to own the system back in the day.

A sa sortie sur Saturn et PS1, le premier Grandia avait été reçu comme un petit jeu faisant les choses en grand. Véritable ode à l'aventure, le jeu proposait de suivre des personnages attachants dans leurs aventures, avec un esprit enthousiaste et optimiste que l'on retrouve encore aujourd'hui dans pas mal de mangas (comme One piece par exemple). Les 90's dans toute leur saveur.

Grandia II sorti en 2000 sur Dreamcast puis PS2, propose une intrigue plus grave et mélancolique. L'histoire se déroule dans un monde sauvé mais meurtri par la victoire Granas, dieu de la lumière sur Valmar, son pendant obscur. De profondes cicatrices entaillent ainsi les continents et les océans. Malgré ces divisions ses habitants mènent leurs existences avec plus ou moins de facilité, se tournant pour la plupart vers le culte de Granas.

Ryudo, mercenaire chasseur de monstres, n'a que faire des bondieuseries et va de ville en ville pour gagner sa vie, jusqu'à ce que son chemin croise celui d'Elena, une cantatrice de Granas, dont le caractère est diamétralement opposé au sien.

Vous l'aurez compris le thème central du jeu est la croyance et son impact sur le libre arbitre. Pendant leurs péripéties les personnages seront régulièrement confrontés au doute ou à des personnages ayant succombé à leurs démons (littéralement). Malgré le pitch apparemment simple (un combat entre la lumière et les ténèbres, on a fait plus original), l'histoire s'en tire assez bien et fait progresser tous ses personnages. Mention spéciale pour le duo Ryudo / Elena, que l'adversité va finir par rapprocher. Grandia II est un des Jrpg qui selon moi propose un des meilleurs développement de ses personnages.

Aussi cette empathie se développe grâce aux très, très nombreux dialogues présents dans le jeu. Leur écriture est excellente, mais leur quantité découragera le joueur peu patient. La rançon d'une implication émotionnelle peu commune dans un jeu. Le jeu n'étant pas traduit en français actuellement, un bon niveau d'anglais est recommandé. Personnellement en 2000 j'y jouais avec le Hachette - Oxford sur les genoux. =)

Jrpg oblige, il me faut aborder le système de combat et de progression des personnages. Les Grandia sont souvent reconnus par les amateurs de Jrpg comme un des, sinon LE meilleur(s) système(s) de combat du genre. Et c'est d'autant plus frustrant de voir ce style si peu représenté dans le genre actuellement.

Les combats se déroulent dans des "arènes" où les personnages peuvent se déplacer (pas comme un FF à l'ancienne en sorte). L'ordre des actions des alliés ou des ennemis est donné par une jauge de temps commune. Arrivé en temps de commande vous pourrez :
- Attaquer ou tenter un Cancel (annuler l'attaque d'un adversaire avec un bon timing).
- Changer de position pour échapper à un ennemi ou adopter une posture défensive.
- Caster un des nombreux sorts du jeu ou des mouvements spéciaux uniques au personnage.
- Utiliser un des nombreux objets offensifs ou défensifs, ou encore changer d'équipement.

Le panel des possibilités données au joueur est donc très large, et si vous vous en emparez, en gérant méticuleusement votre timing et votre placement, vous aurez une bonne maîtrise du champs de bataille. [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sxM9S0ZK2bs]>> UN EXEMPLE DE COMBAT ICI <<[/url]

Associez à cela la possibilité de faire progresser de façon très permissive les personnages et de pouvoir remanier leurs caractéristiques assez facilement, démultipliant les possibilités de build. Vous pourrez ainsi créer un Ryudo courant à 200 à l'heure capable de voler au secours de ses alliés ou d'annuler en urgence une attaque dévastatrice, un Mareg encaissant une quantité incroyable de dégâts, ou un Roan castant des sorts dévastateurs se téléportant en cas d'urgence.

Si les combats sont globalement dynamiques, on peut regretter, un peu à l'instar des très longues phases de dialogue, qu'ils soient hachés par les cinématiques assez longues des sorts alliés comme ennemis. On se retrouvera souvent à vouloir à tout prix cancel un sort ennemi non pas pour en éviter les dégâts, mais pour s'épargner une poignée de secondes de combat ! Certains aimeront cette mise en scène, mais pour moi c'était déjà en 2000 une source de frustration.

Les phases d'exploration sont quant à elles un des points faibles du jeu, les énigmes proposées manquant soit d'originalité soit de clarté. Heureusement vous serez guidés par une boussole pour vous orienter. L'intérêt de Grandia II de ce côté est regrettablement limité selon moi. Certains joueurs pourront à juste titre se plaindre de la linéarité de l'histoire (effectivement il n'y a aucune quête secondaire pour gonfler la durée de vie), mais je considère que les RPG n'ont pas tous besoin d'en proposer.

Techniquement le jeu est toujours assez beau. Le style de la direction artistique a beau avoir vieilli, cette édition "anniversaire" permet d'afficher le jeu en haute définition et surtout en 60 images par seconde, rendant les combats particulièrement agréables à l'œil. Le jeu est globalement stable (quelques très rares ralentissements et  un retour windows sur 34h de jeu environ) et respecte le format 4:3 d'origine. Elle vaut clairement son prix.

Dernier point, et non des moindres, la bande - son du jeu est mé-mo-rable et se paye le luxe de donner dans une grande diversité de styles :
-  Des compositions au synthé / percu / guitare électrique dans un style "très anime 90's".
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vDcE2RvD5gg]>> ICI <<[/url]
- Des cantiques à une ou plusieurs voix accompagnés d'instruments à corde ou à vent.
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FYIDqzTt0w4]>> ICI <<[/url]
- Des duos au piano et au violon pour les moments plus graves.
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_h8-oNY3fe0]>> ICI <<[/url]
- Des morceaux joyeux et rythmés par une flûte de pan, un violon, et des percussions entre autres.
[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xaVvNERzNXA]>> ICI <<[/url]
Du bonheur pour les oreilles et le cerveau =)

Grandia II est donc définitivement un grand RPG, qui mérite qu'on s'y arrête, mais qui présente malheureusement quelques aspects pouvant rebuter le joueur s'y confrontant la première fois. Il sera grandement apprécié par les fans de JRPG et gardera à coup sûr chez eux une place de choix dans leur mémoire. Ayant rencontré un certain succès d'estime auprès de la presse et des joueurs, l'absence de traduction française et sa rigidité l'auront malheureusement condamné à une renommée amoindrie. S'il avait eu le même traitement qu'un certain Skies of Arcadia à l'époque, il aurait pu avoir davantage de succès.

Appréciation personnelle : 16/20
- Manette recommandée.
- Bon niveau d'anglais requis.
- Attention jeu bavard.

L'intro du jeu, pour les nostalgiques : [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYHJbmkjYYc]>> ICI <<[/url]

29941238.review:
Vorsicht subjekt.
Das bessere FInal Fantasy XIII.


Einleitung:
Grandia II hatte ich damals für PC (2002) für Dreamcast und jetzt auch nochmals für Steam. Warum habe ich es so oft gehabt? Das lag daran, dass ich es auf keinem System bisher durchgespielt habe. Entweder ging die 2 CD verloren, oder die Dreamcast wurde eingetauscht (Ja, ich weiß, Schande über mich).

Nun ist es aber geschafft und war es den Kauf wert? Jein.


Spielmechanik
 Hier glänzt das Spiel und hier beginnt mein Vergleich mit FF XIII. Beide haben eher ein schlauchartige Levelstruktur, aber Grandia II hat mehr Explorationsmöglichkeiten ohne das Spiel unnötig in die Länge zu ziehen. Es sind kleine Weggabelungen, nur leicht versteckte Extraräume, die aber alle in ein kurzen Zeit auffindbar sind, wenn man sich nur ein Hauch dafür interessiert. Jemand der Open-World- Spiele satt ist, kann hier Erholung finden.

Das Kampfsystem ist rundenbasiert, hat aber einen guten Kniff, man kann gegnerische Angriffe unterbrechen, Gegner in der Vorbereitungsphase zurückwerfen, gegnerischen Angriffen ausweichen und hat noch weitere Möglichkeiten auf die Gegner zu reagieren. Für ein rundenbasiertes Spiel hat man damit eine viel höhere Reaktionsbandbreite als bei andere Genrevertretern. Dennoch hat man volle Kontrolle über alle Charaktere, nicht so wie in FF XII. Da gibt es nur "Phasenverschiebung". 

Zufallskämpfe? Kein Problem, die Gegner sind alle sichtbar und umgehbar (außer Bosse). Wenn man sie von hinten überrascht, ist man im Vorteil. Dies gibt es auch bei FF XIII, aber die Areale sind in Grandia II größer, man kann sich hinter einer Säule "verstecken" (besonders in der Special Stage nützlich) und den Gegner an einen vorbeiziehen lassen. 

Fähigkeitensystem

Wer FF VII mochte, der wird auch bei Grandia II einen guten Zugang finden. Anstatt, dass jeder Charakter eine spezifische Klasse besitzt, kann man sie mit einem gewissen "Zauberei" (ja die heißen so, also "Eier") ausrüsten. Unterstützereier, Schadenseier, Wald,- Wiesen,- Feuer,- Eis-Eier. 
Zu den Eiern gesellen sich dann sogenante "Skils". Diese sind passiv, wie mehr HP, MP, Ausweichchance, die Möglichkeit mit magischen Angriffen Mana zurückerstattet zu bekommen, bessere Beute finden etc. Skillung mit Substanz (Jeder, der das versteht, darf sich auf die Schulter klopfen).

Die Charaktere steigen natürlich auch Stufen und es lohnt sich natürlich die Fähigkeiten je nach Charakterstärke zu verteilen.
Es gibt auch Spezialattacken. Jeder Charakter lernt nach einiger Zeit ein, oder mehrere dazu. Dies hängt aber nicht vom Level ab, sondern vom Fortschritt in der Geschichte.

Grafik/Sound

Grafisch ist Grandia II zwar stimmig, aber längst kein Augenschmaus mehr. Die Zauber sind zwar teilweise nett animiert, aber man merkt hier die mangelnde Nachbearbeitung. Manche könnten es sogar abschreckend finden, dass sich Zauberanimation und Welt vom Grafikstil teilweise stark unterscheiden.

Der Sound ist nicht besonders. Die Sprache geht in Ordnung. Millenia ist gut vertont, Roan ist nicht die nervige Variante von Hope. Nur Elena hätte hier und da noch ein bisschen mehr Stimmung vertragen können, aber naja FF XIII hat Vanille. 

Geschichte

Hier harkt es. Ich meine, hier ähneln sich FF XIII und Grandia II sehr, auch FF X hat Ansätze davon. Was ich persönlich davon halte, sage ich am Ende.
Positiv, sogar sehr positiv, finde ich die kleinen Geschichten, die sich zwischen den Charakteren widerspiegeln, bzw. wenn man sich Zeit nimmt, mit all den Bewohner der Welt von Grandia II. Es lohnt sich, mehr als einmal mit den Bewohner zu reden, in jeder Stadt mal ein Abendessen im Gasthof zu genießen und zuzusehen, wie sich Rydou und Sky gegenseitig necken und die arme Elena mit ins Boot ziehen. Teilweise liebenswerte Nebencharaktere wie die Chaos-Schauspieltruppe rund um Gonzola (Hieß der so?)

So, nun zur Hauptgeschichte, Vorsicht Spoiler

SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER
SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER
SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER

Wie in FF XIII und gefühlt in vielen anderen japanischen Rollenspielen (und Animes) wird hier wieder die Kirche als "Bösewicht" herangezogen (sie Nazis in fast jedem zweiten Shooter). Nun das ist ok, weil Japaner ihre Ideologie in ihren eigenen Spielen gerne implizieren können (Siehe Maregs Lehren. Diese wurde entgegen aller anderen Meinungen nicht in Frage gestellt, sowie dass das "letzte" Lied, dass dem Stamm Maregs entstammt). 
Und ja es ist populär, schon seit Jahren, die "Folge deinem Herzen" - Melodie zu spielen. Gott gibt es nicht, der Mensch ist sein eigener Herr. Und doch ist es ja gerade jene Ideologie, die ihrer eigenen Lehre (Der Mensch soll sich nicht zu einem Gott erheben etc.) widerspricht. Denn der Mensch macht sich selbst zu Gott, weil er sich selbst über alles andere stellt und ehrt sich mit jeder Beschäftigung, die seinem Herzenswunsch entspricht ("Ich tu das für mich" Rydou). Also verehrt der Mensch keinen Gott, aber sich selbst. 
Hier wäre eine Differenzierung angebrachter. Man mag an Gott glauben, oder nicht. Das muss jeder selbst für sich gut argumentieren können, doch muss sich dieses Spiel die Kritik gefallen lassen, dass es sich hier widerspricht. 
Einerseits sagt es: Wir bauchen keine Götter und der Mensch soll sich nicht zu Gott erheben. Anderseits macht jeder Mensch sich mit der "Ich-mich-meiner-mir"-Ideologie des "Herzens" selbst zu (s)einem Gott.  Schlussendlich die Idee des Helden, von dem alle "abhängig" sind, widerspricht dem Wunsch der Unabhängigkeit von einem Gott.

Well aged JRPG, still fun. Still has great music, characters, combat system, and story. (Results may vary [hueheuhue])

If you can tolerate this era of JRPG story that lays the religion on thick then by all means play it.
The gameplay is the thing that still stands out the most. Certain characters may take a while to shine/become likeable. But character development happens in huge chunks at a time. There's no slow methodical thought process analysis or anything. It's a fast game anyway; It's extremely linear with no optional bosses, post game, or much reason to grind. You'll blow through it in about 30-40 hours with no grinding. (For an RPG that's basically the minimum amount of hours).

It has SUB AND DUB FOR ALL TASTES. (English and Japanese VOs).

The game's not very difficult so long as you know the mechanics/to actually level up your skills/stats(Skill book buffs if what I mean)/eggs. I'm not going to spoil any "strats" or anything (ofc).

Ah, Grandia 2. One of the first JRPGs I've ever played... and I played this game a LOT when I had it on my crappy old PC and on PS2 much later. Now with this Anniversary edition, I FINALLY got to hear the japanese voice acting too, which is a huge plus for me. Nostalgia threads were pulled hard while playing this game... Buuut... without further ado, let's go with pros and cons...

Pros:

- Unique battle system. Though turn based, it relies on how fast your characters are, how quickly they can act on the battle field, and if you master the usage of the battle meter... as I call it, haha, you can easily win battles without taking any damage at all, even during boss fights. 

- Music. I love Noriyuki Iwadare's OST for this game. It's uplifting, exciting, full of suspence, sad, beautiful... you name it! Battle music always gets me pumped (even after hearing it for the 3000th time). 

- Some of the characters. I love Ryudo's attitude. At first he's pretty much an a-hole, but you can see him mature to a young man with a more open mind. Millenia and Tio are probably the most lovable women in this game. Oh... and Melfice... that Melfice... *fangirls* I love him! Because he's such a hot baddie <3

- English voice cast has done a very good job at bringing the characters alive. 

Cons:

- Story: Even though I like it, it's still pretty predictable. This game has that little something that has left its mark in my heart, but the story is your every JRPG ever, with cliched plot twists and characters. Good versus Evil, save the world, blah blah... 

- Sound effects are very loud, and the voiced parts sometimes get interrupted when the scene goes on. 

- Graphics are sort of old-fashioned, but I don't mind, because graphics are never everything - you can make a very pretty and realistic looking videogame, but if everything else sucks, people won't come back to it. And hey, at least there are no longer dark round shadows underneath the characters anymore! :D

Middle-ground (Neither good or bad)

- Japanese voice cast. Maybe it's because I was so used to hear the english voice cast, the japanese one fell flat. Most of the time the lines sounded very awkward compared to the situation they were said in, and they lacked any kind of feeling to them. Maybe it's a cultural thing, I don't know. But I must say it was worth listen to it. I liked it despite the occasional awkwardness.

Soms dan blijkt maar weer de kracht van recensies. Een mensenleven geleden zat ik bij een vriendje thuis in een anime-magazine te bladeren en ik was verkikkerd op de enthousiaste woorden over deze titel. Het zou een moddervette game zijn met een scheldende hoofdpersoon (wooow!) en personages gingen gruwelijk dood. Ook de game mechanics zouden een verfijnde uitwerking zijn van de battles in de vorige Grandia (1997), met meer keuzemogelijkheden en vechttactieken. De recensent in kwestie was jubelend over de vele CGI-effecten die tussen de gevechten in zijn geplaatst. En toch ebde mijn interesse weg, want de game was natuurlijk niet te krijgen in Nederland en ik wist nog niet hoe je met illegale kopieën Japanse games in je huiskamer kon halen. Tot mijn grote verbazing dook Grandia 2  op in een geremasterde PC-versie op een Steam Summer Sale, nog behoorlijk prijzig ook (10 euro in de sale, 30 euro 'normaal'.) In een opwelling heb ik hem toch aangeschaft om te kijken of de recensie destijds het bij het goede eind had.

Om het eerste grote kritiekpunt te benoemen: de PC-port is schandalig slecht. Het heeft irritante bugs en veel lag (?) dat je niet verwacht bij een deugdelijke port, waarbij recht wordt gedaan aan het medium waarop je de game speelt. Bij een van de eerste 'boss battles' (tegen Millenia) bleek er dus zelfs een bug in te zitten waardoor je niet verder kan spelen en de game vastloopt. (Je verzint het niet: als je de battle tutorial doet voordat je de boss battle ingaat, loopt de game automatisch vast. Kun je niks anders aan doen dan opnieuw beginnen...) Behalve dat ik moest wennen aan de gedateerde graphics en het langzamere speeltempo t.o.v. moderne games, was het dus een extra hobbel dat ik de slordige oneffenheden erbij op de koop toe moest nemen.Gelukkig bleek 'Grandia II' (2000) als  klassieker op zichzelf staand krachtig genoeg om door te bijten en mee te gaan in de epische vertelling. 

Meer nog dan in het vorige deel heeft het een beklijvende verhaallijn vol met religieuze verwijzingen naar een klassieke oerstrijd tussen goed en kwaad. Ryuodo is een sympathieke protagonist als de archetypische rebelse jongere die God noch gebod kent. Hij vloekt en daagt God (uit deze wereld) meermalen uit om te bewijzen dat Hij bestaat. Vrouwen worden ronduit seksistisch bejegend. Als dertiger vind ik hem iets minder stoer dan ik hem als tiener had gevonden, maar ergens is het ook de charme van dit soort games dat je zo bekend bent met de gelijksoortige personages en voorspelbare verhaallijnen. Ook 'love interest' en maagdelijk nonnetje Elena is leuk, zeker als het plot een absurde wending neemt en ze onverwacht een duistere kant krijgt. De andere personages laat ik even in het midden om spoilers te voorkomen. 

Maar een game staat of valt met de gameplay, en die is gelukkig meer dan oké. Het begint wat traag als je nog met één of twee karakters op stap bent, maar hoe meer karakters, speciale vaardigheden en magische spreuken in de groep komen, hoe hectischer en sneller het wordt. Uiteindelijk is het gewoon turn based, maar door de snelheid van de gevechten voelt het als realtime. En elke aanval levert vermakelijke CGI-sequenties op die de gevechtssituaties wat sjeu geven. Het upgrade-systeem werkt wat omslachtig met verschillende punten voor 'moves' en 'magic', maar na verloop van tijd is het makkelijk te volgen en levert het verschillende mogelijkheden op om de teamtactiek zelf mee vorm te geven. Toch is het jammer dat - zoals bij wel meer JRPG's- het veranderen van statistieken weinig uitmaakt, want de game is makkelijk genoeg als je de battles niet overslaat en enigszins het juiste level hebt voor de betreffende boss. Het speelt door de toegankelijke moeilijkheidsgraad wel lekker vlot weg, met weinig momenten dat je moet grinden of belemmerd wordt omdat je eerder essentiële fouten hebt gemaakt.

28857231.review:
After a year of slowly playing through this port of [i]Grandia II[/i] to savor every moment of it and compare it to my memories of previous playthroughs of other versions of the game, I can satisfyingly state my thoughts on [i]Grandia II Anniversary Edition[/i].

[h1]The Game & Series[/h1]

If you haven't played any of the games in the series (yes, there are mutliple games - no, none of the games that were brought out of Japan are connected at all), this is, as the product page describes, a Japanese RPG. Like the [i]Final Fantasy[/i] series games of old, the [i]Grandia[/i] series features a semi-turn-based battle system, where characters can only attack once they are ready to act. The [i]Grandia[/i] series raises the stakes beyond [i]Final Fantasy[/i]'s ATB System as each character and enemy has their own speeds that they traverse the IP Gauge in order to reach the Command Entry point, subsequent actions have associated time costs to them, those actions can be countered and cancelled by choosing specific actions of your own (and enemies can do it to you as well), and characters are required to traverse the battlefield to reach their target (depending on what action is chosen), making battles require a little bit more thinking to them.

Of the three main games and the lone side game that were localized, [i]Grandia II[/i], to me, fits cleanly in the center of the bunch. [i]Grandia[/i] is often cited as having the best storyline in the series, [i]Grandia Xtreme[/i] is a game purely focused on the combat system (and it's the best of the series in that regard) but suffers from a barebones plot that is simply there just to advance the game, and [i]Grandia III[/i] is visually the prettiest of the series, but its plot and characters (well, the ones that stick around anyway) are nothing to write home about and the combat is a hair under [i]Xtreme[/i]'s.

[i]Grandia II[/i] fits snugly in between all of the rest - it's story is solid yet not to the degree of the original and its combat is more refined than the original's but not as much as its successors'. You'll find yourself sticking around for the script writing (or, at least, how it was localized) and the characters/characterizations more than the overall plot, which is basically nothing more than "Mercenary becomes bodyguard for (holy) Priestess, Evil arises, Mercenary-turned-hero must take his party to unravel evil plot and save everyone." If you love the top video game voice acting talent of the early 2000s, a fair number of them can be found here (Cam Clarke, Jennifer Hale, and Paul Eiding, just to name three) - heck, even the voice of Ariel from [i]Disney's The Little Mermaid[/i] has a prominent role that will completely make you question your childhood if you've ever watched the movie.

[h1]The Anniversary Edition itself[/h1]

[i]Grandia II Anniversary Edition[/i] is the third port of the original [i]Grandia II[/i] release (made back in 2000 for the Sega Dreamcast). Prior to its release, neither the PlayStation 2 port nor the original PC port were completely perfect replications of the original release, each with their own issues that marred the releases. The Anniversary Edition's code is based on the original Dreamcast release, though this comes with its own issues.

The original game's code on the Dreamcast must have been so completely unique to the hardware, because every single port, including the Anniversary Edition, features bugs, glitches, or issues not present in the original version. Notably, the Anniversary Edition has: Camera clipping issues, graphical issues (mostly related to casting spells), audio issues (sound balance issues (some effects too low, others far too loud and overpowering), sound clips not playing at all when they should, sound effects not sounding correctly, odd looping, etc.), and a "hacky" solution that sometimes causes text/audio desync in longer cinematic sequences or auto-advancing text segments that are voiced. Perhaps it is my system's specs, but I also frequently encountered issues where, out of the blue, the game would stutter in framerate for ~30 seconds and then go completely back to normal.

[i]Grandia II Anniversary Edition[/i] does have plenty of options for the end user to toggle through, including 60 FPS battles, but this feature was not found in the original Dreamcast version and is not necessary to your enjoyment - it was fine in 30 FPS back in the 2000s. The screen size options (note: this game is natively 4:3, as that's how the game and its assets were originally developed), anti-aliasing, and such are welcome additions. Apparently, Gung Ho and Skybox Labs determined that a new engine for shadows was needed, which in part contributes to some of the spellcasting issues, but the shadows do look much better graphically than they originally did. (The new shadows do cause a lighting issue in the final dungeon, however.)

Gung Ho, despite opening up a survey long before announcing the project (which culminated in this port being made) where they listened to the responses and developed the Anniversary Edition off of the original, superior Dreamcast version, chose to enlist Skybox Labs to develop the port... a decision which ultimately ended up producing a flawed game that, to this day, is still not up to the standards of the original Dreamcast release. Gung Ho saw fit to cut their support for fixing the release after a time had passed, without fixing all of the game's issues. The game is still beatable, but you will definitely notice flaws that are apparent. Gung Ho should have made a better choice in developer or bothered to release the game in a finished, unflawed state - I don't know whether Skybox was given an unrealistic deadline for the game by Gung Ho and were only permitted a certain window of post-launch support or if Skybox was not the best developer for the job, but the result is what you have here.

[h1]To Buy or Not to Buy?[/h1]

Personally, I feel as though the [i]Grandia[/i] series has one of the premiere combat systems found in Japanese RPGs and I strongly recommend that people experience this game in particular. Should you get [i]Grandia II Anniversary Edition[/i] though? Well, that depends on your situation/scenario/preferred gaming style.

[list]
[*] Do you have a Sega Dreamcast?
If yes, I recommend skipping [i]Grandia II Anniversary Edition[/i] and, instead, tracking down a copy of the Dreamcast version. To this day, over ten years later, it's still the most superior version on all fronts.
[*] If the answer to the previous question was no, then my next recommendation would be to purchase one (it was a great, albeit short-lived system and it does have a pretty good library of titles that were only found on it and haven't been ported since) along with the Dreamcast version of [i]Grandia II[/i].
[*] If the above option is not feasible, then you have two further options. If you prefer gaming on the PC, have a laptop and can take your gaming on the go, or like other bonuses found in this release, then go ahead and pick up [i]Grandia II Anniversary Edition[/i] (Hard Mode will make the game more challenging if you haven't already played the game if the base difficulty is too low, but veterans will have no issue beating the game on Hard Mode and getting all 36 Achievements). If you have a PlayStation 2, the port of [i]Grandia II[/i] for that would also be an option, though I would probably recommend the Anniversary Edition more than it, unless you have an older computer that can't handle running this version adequately (because the game was rebuilt, it is not simply an emulator running the original Dreamcast version, hence the higher system requirements!).
[/list]

[h1]Final Verdict:[/h1]
Should you play [i]Grandia II Anniversary Edition[/i]? Well, you should play [i]Grandia II[/i] in some way, shape, or form, but I honestly don't think [i]Grandia II Anniversary Edition[/i] is the best, most-preferred method of doing so.

28034832.review:
Это классика! Одна из лучших JRPG! Лучшая игра на Дримкаст Ностальгия!
Это и многое другое можно прочитать в большинстве обзоров и мнений на эту игру. 
И ведь действительно в те годы когда «Грандия» вышла она была эталонной. 
- Продуманная пошаговая механика с кучей фишек.
- Харизматичные герои
- Драматичный и трогательный сюжет.
 - И кроме «Финалки» почти полное отсутствие конкурентов.
 У этой игры всё было, что бы создать тот культ адепты  которого, сейчас не глядя, спустя 15 лет её покупаю и, не играя, ставят 10:10.
Однако как не прискорбно это осознавать её время ушло…
Пройдемся по старинке:

Сюжет.
Это основа основ JRPG, многие только из-за этого в них и играют. Он тут никакой. Я согласен, что когда мы были мельче и выбор скудней подобные истории могли легко пробить и на слез, однако сейчас все эти приёмы не работаю. Культ «тех фанатов» стал старше, а новые юные потребители просто избалованнее. Им сейчас есть из чего выбрать. В результате, он никого не тронет. Мотивация ГГ и его команды пропитана глупостью и наивностбю как в дешевых детских аниме где все пафосно орут про «милое доброе вечное», но в это абсолютно не веришь. Уж больно по детски всё. Все сюжетные ходы видны наперед, плюсом ко всему даже «ачивки» спойлерят один из ключевых сюжетных ходов.

Боёвка.
Да она интересная, но ей в этой игре негде «разгуляться». Поначалу вам доступна только одна сложность «Нормал». И на этой сложности умереть почти не реально. «Почти» потому что боссы тут представляют хоть какую-то опасность.  Такие фишки как «маневры» «защита» тут попросту лишены смысла. Вы просто из раза в раз будет прожимать на самую мощную абилку и всё. Больше делать ничего не надо. Присутствует странный и не продуманный менеджмент манны, но он решается банальным «дошёл до города – взял 100 фруктов на МП» и до конца игры хватит.
Мир.
Локации самая слабая часть игры. Они мелкие и однообразие. Придя в город на входе вы встретите 1 магаз и 1 гостиницу. Остальное лишь декорации. Есть дома, в которые можно зайти, но в них ничего полезно нет. Максимум это строчка диалога от очередного NPC ни о чем . А те локации где уже идёт не посредственно путешествия и сражения это вообще ужас. Это либо равнина с изредка стоящими «камнями-деревьями-палками» которые образую почти коридор, либо чёртов лабирин (к концу их чертовски много) и то и то унылое, а последнее так вообще жутко раздражает.

Вердикт.
В нынешнее время ПК уже не испытывает такого острого дефицита в JRPG, а по сему отпала необходимость во «всеядности». А если не это и не ностальгия, то ничего не может замотивировать человека в это играть. Лучше запустить ту же 13-ую ФФ от которой все плюются, но она в разы разнообразней и вариативней Грандии. Сейчас эта игра просто безликое ископаемое и не больше, не меньше.

Порт.
Стоит отметить отдельно. Двухкнопочное управление испортить не возможно, но хоть кнопки позволили переназначать. Однако, даже тут есть косяк. Экран срезан с двух сторон по бокам. Иными словами эту игру так и не адаптировали под 16:9. Какое бы вы разрешение не поставили она будет обрезанной. 

P.S. Русского нету и потому я качал убогий русификатор времен ПС1. В нем, кстати, глючат ачивки, они просто не получаются. По крайней мере, 3 из них.

28026324.review:
After playing a lot of modern indie RPG's and JRPG's, no one really seems to 'get it.'  Developers are being retro for the sake of being retro, so I feel like I'm playing Final Fantasy I's and II's again in another creator's eye, and that's not very exciting to me.

I judge the fun factor of a RPG based on almost every detail, but the big 4 are:  Gameplay, Story, Characters, and Music

Gameplay:  Grandia II attempts to do what Chrono Trigger attempted(and succeeded) to do with RPG's- and that is to spice up the formula.  I really like the unique turn meter and combat system.  Countering, dodging, attacking, and buff/debuff magic all receive their fair due attention instead of having one core strategy and using it to annihilate all enemies.  Sure, magic is OP and you get enough MP refreshments via save points to spam your most powerful magic attack, but many enemies' resistances are so strong it is faster to know who to hit with and who to cast magic and what type instead of spamming one spell over and over.  

This was my first play through and a I chose Hard- there were spots that were genuinely difficult where others seemed to breeze by, only one occurance did I grind to force the boss to be easier.  The other time, I COULDN'T grind as the save point was in a 'point-of-no-return' area, and it took a lot of trial and error to realize one character's special move affects a lot more than the description lets on, so the translation or at least the descriptions could have done with more symbols showing exactly what it can cause the enemy to inhibit or at least better wording.

Story:  I won't give much away here, but it is an enthralling adventure with a distinctive world with huge landmarks and many dangers that kept me interested in what was around the next corner for the protagonist.

Characters:  Oh, did I say protagonist?  Within the first 20 minutes of the game you'll see how much of a 'hero' this guy is.  I had never played a JRPG before this one that followed such a realistic(or at least non-stereotypical), outspoken, and 'I'm done with your ****' type of 'hero.'  It was definitely refreshing, and at times cringe-worthy to see how badly he insults a party member early on just because of their differences.  The interactions between the characters were made better with Grandia's signature 'camp and chat' feature where certain parts of the story have you selecting different characters and reading their banter on water-cooler topics that don't necessarily effect the main story.

Music:  It's actually ok, nothing great or forgettable.  If anything, it isn't repetitive, or at least it never rubbed me the wrong way unlike many other JRPG's.  I can't recall any outstanding pieces, but it serves its purpose.

My only complaint is there is no way to fast forward or skip the long magic cutscene animations.  Of all JRPG's I've played I've never had a reason to use the fast forward feature that many are receiving with these anniversary and HD editions- but Grandia II sorely needed it.

I had a lot of fun with this one and look forward to coming back to it later on!

Really enjoyed this game when it was ported to the PS2, and it's still one of my favorite cult hit JRPGs, alongside Xenosaga and .hack.  Story is fairly generic and predictable, but the environments and dungeons are pretty diverse, character interactions and development is respectable to good, and the dialogue, while cringe at times, reminds me of a time when anime dubs were enjoyable for sounding cartoony and campy.

 The biggest draw to this game, however, is the combat, which is a unique mix of turnbased and real time battle.  Character movement before or after an attack can lead to an attack  missing, and there are ways of coordinating your party's attacks to do extra damage through combos or to delay an enemy's use of a powerful skill or spell.  Boss battles are satisfying in difficulty, and you can gain extra items by killing parts of them before killing the main body (you should anyway, because many times these parts are buffing the boss or throwing extra attacks and debuffs/ailments on your party, so taking those parts out quickly helps you out).

For those who enjoy waifus, Millenia is bae.  Ryudo is also husbando material for you ladies out there.  And Mareg is a bro.

The anniversary edition has enhanced visual and audio (essentially, it's cleaned up), but don't expect a remaster like the FFX Collection.  But if you can look past the dated graphics and the occasionally cringe dialogue/voice acting, and you're looking for a JRPG fix in between FF15 and Personal 5, give this a try.  It's a flawed gem, but a gem nonetheless.

I passed over Grandia II when I was growing up, but I remember it being highly regarded at the time.  I went into this PC version with high expectations based on that and I was pretty underwhelmed.

First the good parts:
- The translation is pretty decent
- The PC port seems alright
- Being a Grandia game, the battles can at times be engaging
- Being a Grandia game, there's lots of dialogue and character interaction if you want it.

But now for the bad parts...
- The story is mostly generic and stupid in a very JRPG way.  It's typical of JRPGs of its era.  It's the sort of plot that I might have thought was good when I was a 12-year-old, but most adults would be embarrassed by it. The characters are mostly annoying most of the time.  Their behavior is juvenile and tedious, which makes it hard to care about them.  The dialog is good when the characters are just chatting, but awful when they're talking about anything related to the plot, especially towards the end.  I've heard enough JRPG monologues about how the power of the heart will overcome any obstacle, thanks.
- The battle system had potential, but throws away nearly all of that potential by 1) making battles take too long by using any strategy except unleashing powerful AOE attacks over and over, and 2) making all the AOE attacks consist of 20-second-long low-budget CGI animations.  Because there are save points where you can heal all over the place, the most rational course of action is to just use Sky Dragon Slash or "Zap All" or whatever every single battle.  This means you spend 80% of the time in battles watching the same crappy 320x240 animations over and over again. There's no option to skip these animations. Not fun. This is not a game that respects the value of its players' time.

To be honest, I'm a little confused by other reviews seeming to praise the story.  Maybe I'm just getting to old to enjoy this sort of thing.

They should have taken their CGI budget and spent it on writing instead.

23918455.review:
I made it through about half of the game (based on my location and looking at a guide) before giving up.  I love classic RPGs, and I actually owned a Dreamcast as a kid.  I was excited to get to play Grandia II for the first time after all these years since I missed out on it when it was first released.  I wanted very badly to enjoy the game and then be able to recommend it to others, but I didn't enjoy it and I can't recommend it.

Let's start with what Grandia II does well.  It has that classic early 2000s feel to it.  The character and environment designs gave me a Skies of Arcadia vibe.  The music is also excellent, and when it doesn't crash, the game runs buttery smooth on a modern PC.  Despite the low poly count, the visuals are excellent and very crisp.

So what's wrong with it?  The game is a complete chore to play.  While I will give the game props for trying something new with a turned-based battle system, it feels incredibly slow and each battle actually eats up a fair amount of real time.    Spell and special attack animations are also extremely lengthy.  I've played a ton of RPGs, and I've never had my patience tested this badly.  While the visuals are great, the locations you visit are all extremely small.  To make up for this, you are thrust into lengthy battle after lengthy battle as you traverse the small, uninteresting environments.  In addition to the environments being bland, there is no minimap and the horrendous camera makes navigating a real pain.

What about the story or the characters?  Can either of those redeem the game?  No.  The story is literally Light vs. Darkness, with some bit of Darkness being contained in seemingly every town you visit.  Everything just feels so bland.  In a certain sense, to the point at which I stopped playing, it felt like Final Fantasy I level storytelling.  The characters don't change or grow in any way during the first half of the game, and their interactions feel extremely forced.

I should also say a word about instability.  The game apparently crashes frequently and without warning for a number of people; others occasionally experience serious slowdown.  I experienced a grand total of one very surprising crash and fairly frequent (but brief slowdown).  If you plan on buying this, make sure it runs well for you during the two hour refund window.  Battles take ages, and losing progress between save points over and over again would become maddening.

Even if you don't mind slow games and love classic JRPGs, I'd still say pass on this one unless you've played it before and know you are going to like it.  If you want a slow-paced game that is a lot of fun and features well-written characters and dialog, give Legend of Heroes a try instead.

23037823.review:
Чудеса бывают!!
Спустя 15 лет, после выхода Grandia 2 на Dreamcast'е, её улучшенная версия выходит в Steam. Поклонники и олдскульщики вне себя от восторга.
Это всё та же, любимая нами Грандия, с некоторыми косметическими и геймплейными улучшениями в виде:
[list]
    [*]некоторые текстурки теперь в HD качестве, жаль только спрайты не перерисовали (компас, action bar, картинки персонажей во время диалогов);
    [*]различные настройки графики (соотношение сторон экрана, сглаживание, разрешение), глаз теперь не нарадуется;
    [*]бои в 60fps'ах;
    [*]японская озвучка с англ. субтитрами (субтитры иногда идут вперед ^_^);
    [*]поддержка геймпада и т.д.
[/list]
Конечно при старте продаж игры имелись проблемы в техническом плане (вылеты, зависания, пропадания звука и т.д.), но разработчики всё исправили с патчами. Остались, конечно, проблемы с затемнением текстур при использовании некоторых магических умений, а также с исчезанием некоторых частей объектов при очень близком подлете камеры. Но это уже никак не мешает наслаждаться великолепной игрой.
Если вы любитель jrpg и еще не играли в Grandia® II Anniversary Edition, то не проходите мимо. Игра действительно стоящая. В неё интересно играть не смотря на линейный, но продуманный сюжет. В нём прекрасно сочетаются комедийные и трагичные моменты. Противники здесь злые как и должно быть: так и хочется дать им по мордасам. А за героев переживаешь и пакуешь их в крутые шмотки ^_^

22274773.review:
Versión para PCs actuales del clásico de Dreamcast, al que le han retocado ALGUNOS gráficos, añadido sombras y mejorado la resolución de los textos para adaptarlos a los estándares gráficos contemporáneas. No obstante, no te dejes engañar, porque las texturas siguen siendo las mismas. El resultado es un juego extraño, en donde conviven polígonos perfectamente trazados con otros elementos gráficos con una calidad paupérrima para los tiempos que corren.

Para colmo, sólo han elevado a 60 FPS las batallas; el resto sigue a 30 FPS. Es como si quisieran hacer caja con esta adaptación pero sin complicarse demasiado la vida. El resto es totalmente igual, tanto para bien como para mal. O, lo que es lo mismo, que disfrutaremos del mismo estilo de juego popularizado por los "Final Fantasy", los "Shining Force" o el "CronoTirgger" basado en combates por turnos en donde combinamos multitud de ataques y magias.

Ahora bien, eso también significará lidiar con todos los defectos que este juego tenía en el pasado, caso de la imposibilidad de salvar donde queramos, la obligación de tragarnos escenas cansinas previas a un combate, el no poder abandonar una batalla para volver al menú, los movimientos de cámara imposibles, el comportamiento errático de algunos personajes en el campo de batalla, la machaconería de los infinitos textos, la casi absoluta falta de voces digitalizadas, los aburridos silencios durante algunas escenas o los ya famosos comportamientos ortopédicos de los personajes cuando interactuan con terceros.

Eso sí, conviene dejar una cosa clara: El juego da problemas. Los más habituales son las caídas del framerate, una leve asincronía entre textos y voces, las animaciones a trompicones y algunos problemas con los sonidos. En los foros recomiendan varias soluciones, las cuales recojo escuetamente aquí por si a alguno le sirviese:

• En el caso de las tarjetas gráficas NVIDIA, los problemas de las animaciones a trompicones se resuelven (o eso dicen), tocando la configuración del panel de control de la tarjeta. Consultar foros para más detalles. En mi caso lo resolví lanzando el cliente de Steam con privilegios de administrador (una barbaridad, pero así es).

• Hay gente que dice haber resuelto algunos problemas con los sonidos y las animaciones instalando un MOD. Consultar foros para más información.

• Los propios creadores recomiendan desactivar las sombras y los 60 FPS de las batallas para intentar lidiar con los problemas gráficos.

NO todo el mundo ha logrado solucionar estos problemas siguiendo estos consejos, ojo.

En resumidas cuentas, que nadie espere un Grandia II en HD puro y duro, sino una versión discutiblemente remozada que adolece de fallos. Es, por tanto, requisito indispensable disponer de una dosis de nostalgia mínima para poder disfrutarlo. Los más jóvenes quedan avisados de ello. Y todos, jóvenes y no tan jóvenes, quedan advertidos de que pueden tener problemas con su funcionamiento.

Como detalle final decir que este juego está pidiendo a gritos un remake (más bien reboot) con las tecnologías actuales. Un trabajo desde cero que actualice el nivel gráfico del juego, que ponga fin a las interminables parrafadas de textos y que adapte el estilo de juego a una época en donde el ritmo es más intenso. Todo ello, claro está, combinado con una corrección de todas las carencias de las que adolece.

PD: Algunos problemas, como los parones, se solucionan iniciando Steam en modo administrador.

Con amor para Millenia.

22111436.review:
[h1]"Sister, please, pray for us!"

"...I'm afraid I cannot help you anymore. There is no God." [/h1]

Oh, Grandia II! One of the best games from my childhood that were fortunately ported by GungHo America to Steam. Originally a Dreamcast title released in 2001, ported later to the PS2 in 2002 and later to Steam as the Anniversary Edition in 2015, this classic JRPG still holds well even after 15 years of it's initial release, mostly for it's memorable story and innovative combat system! 

The story in Grandia II revolves around Ryudo, a Geohound (a sort of bounty hunter in the Grandia universe), moved around from place to place, taking requests the normal folks would generally despise. One day, he received a letter of invitation, or a job request, to escort a band of Sisters of Granas for their usual prayer ritual from the nearby village. Things unfortunately went south and from a basic escort job, Ryudo is now stuck in a potential catastrophic event that may decimate the world. 

Before moving on to the pros and cons, I would just like to mention that I may be bias in recommending this as this game is held dearly by me as one of my favorite titles ever but I'll try to point out all the positive and negative aspects of this port.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
[*] As I've mentioned earlier, this game has an absolute [b]BRILLIANT[/b] story! The plot itself is captivating with a mind bending plot twist occurring at the second half of the game. I've played a lot of RPGs and I can firmly say that Grandia II has definitely one of the best ones!
[*] Every playable characters are surprisingly lovable! From the sarcastic and no-bullshit Ryudo to the calm and wise Mareg, every character stands out on their own and their lines perfectly matched with their attitude that Game Arts portrayed them to be.
[*] One more thing about the characters are their lines. Seriously, read them all if you can! You can find tidbits of Ryudo and Helena's love-hate relationship, Mareg's pearls of wisdom, Millenia's flirty-but-chaotic tone. Even talking with NPCs will net you awesome dialogues between the characters! ([b]PRO TIP[/b]: Make sure to talk to everyone at least TWICE. There's always 2 or 3 different conversations you can have each time you talk to anyone) 
[*] Innovative and dynamic combat system! I think this one is what separate Grandia II with the other RPGs at the time. What I mean by dynamic is that everyone moves freely in the battlefield during their turn. Instead of the usual turn-based battles (a la ATB from the Final Fantasy series), once the character's turn is reached, they will run forward to their enemy to land the blows. This makes it interesting since the character, implied to both friendlies and foes, can miss or evade just by moving a bit. Also, another interesting mechanic in combat is the Cancel system. Every character have the basic Combo or Critical attack to use each turn. The Critical is weaker from the pair, since it only hit once, but when used when an opponent's turn, it will cancel the said turn, shoving the said opponent queue lower and allows for tactical comeback.
[*] Great character's customization via skills and magic equip. In Grandia, magic comes from an equip Mana Egg you'll find across the game. Each have different spells, whether offensive or defensive, and can be equip by anyone, in AND out of battles! So basically, any character can be a healer or damager, with the limiting factors comes only with the mana pool and the character's stats. Same goes with skills, where upon finding and leveling up skill books, you can equip skills to boost the character's ability on what build you decide to use on him/her.
[*] Basically an all around decent port with a few minor quirks (I'll list them down in the Cons). During the whole 40 hours of my playtime, the game never crashed on me once. There's also an option to turn on VSync and Anti-aliasing via an external launcher.
[*] The game supports both Japanese and English voice over. I used the Japanese voices most of the time since I forgot how cringey the English voice actors sound in the game (still good compared to the other JRPGs at the time though). I switch to English only when there's a plot heavy cut scene comes up because they don't have subs for it. The option is available via the said external launcher.
[*] Full controller support (I used the standard XBOX 360 controller) with customizable buttons.
[*] An option to play in Hard Mode right off the bat. I suggest going for this since the game is quite easy once you got the hang of the mechanics.
[*] A perfect 100% game is moderately easy to achieve in one play. I took a little bit over the 40 hours mark in Hard Mode to complete the game with all the achievements unlocked. Surprisingly, it only took me a a little grind to get the 2000 enemies killed. Of course, you have to look in very nook and cranny for hidden treasures to ensure you didn't missed any specific ones, namely the "Bling" and "Put A Notch in it" achievements.
[/list]

[h1]NEUTRAL[/h1]
[list]
[*] In combat, the HP bar for ALL enemies is shown clearly to you, even bosses! Bosses with > 9999 HP will be shown as ????/???? but with the bars shown, you can estimate when he's going to die. It's useful but I think it dissolve the suspense that the usual RPG boss fights have. 
[/list]

[h1]CONS[/h1]
[list]
[*] The biggest pet peeve I have with this game is that it doesn't support a native widescreen support. Sure, you can change the resolution and toggle the widescreen option but what it does is just stretch the aging 4:3 camera, making the game unbearably ugly. If the widescreen toggle is turned off, you'll have to settle playing with a letterbox resolution to the end.
[*] The Japanese voice over is not sync with the English dialogue. The voice get cuts over prematurely if the text advances way faster than the actual voices. It doesn't happen when you're using the English voice though.
[*] Camera controls in the fields and dungeons are frustrating and dizzying at times. Since the developers tend to hid items behind walls, you have to rotate the camera nonstop to spot it and it's annoying. Also, the camera zooms in on Ryudo when you stopped moving even for a second.
[*] Some text glitched out passed the text box. 
[*] 30 FPS-locked. Yeap, it's still there. It's nothing major really but the characters does seems floaty at time during walking. Good thing is that battles runs in fully glorious 60 FPS! That's why it feels fast and frantic at times.
[*] Although the game runs smoothly at 30 and 60 FPS, there's a few area (namely the snowy mountains) where the FPS drops a bit. Not really important but I supposed I should mention it.
[*] Opening the save and loading screens took ages! 
[*] The field interactions are unnecessarily and painfully [b]SLOW[/b]! For example, when you're climbing a ladder, everyone will take turns to slowly navigate the ladder and you CAN'T move until everyone's done. Missed something up there? You might as well go and order takeouts in the meantime.
[*] Textures sometimes glitched out and you can see through walls (whoa)
[*] In combat, the game shows exactly what your opponents will do, even when it's not their turn yet. Even though it does make things simpler, I think it just ruins the difficulty. (Oh, the boss is using his ultimate move after this? Let's Cancel it!)
[/list]

[h1]To conclude, even with the minor technical quirks and aging game engine, I give Grandia II Anniversary Edition a nostalgic and epic [b]5/5[/b]! Truly a masterpiece of a JRPG! [/h1]

To the fan of the series and also JRPG fans, I can assure you that the money spent is well worth it! I would also recommend to use [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/330390/discussions/0/520519112492477670/]Leandro Eidi's HD Mod[/url] where it adds a few nice little HD touch to the apparently aging game.

21675369.review:
TL;DR: Get this game, it's a real treat that deserves the praise it's gotten over the years and the votes that got it Greenlit for a Steam release. There are only 3 issues I encountered while playing that I wish could be fixed:
1) Quite a few typos throughout the game.
2) De-syncing of the audio and text dialogue gets really jarring at the halfway point of the game and beyond (this was using Japanese audio not English).
3) No translation whatsoever for the animated CG cutscenes, which is a shame.

[Story - average]: The story is pretty linear, simple and cliche. But that doesn't stop it from being engaging and pretty solid with how it's told. Even with the cinematics not having translations, I was able to figure out what was going on based on what was being shown which isn't always easy to do. The pace is kind of like a rollercoaster, once it takes off, there's no stopping it until it ends.

[Characters - excellent]: The most entertaining part of the game was probably the responses Ryudo had in the early parts of the game. The game also has an unusual feature allowing your party to have dinner scenes at inns where they talk about fellow party members or story related things. Sometimes for hilarious results and other times gives chances for developing the characters because the main story pretty much starts off at max speed and stops for nothing. All of your party members are likeable (although Elena got grating at several points for me).

[Graphics - average]: By today's standards it's obviously dated, but I would've been impressed to see graphics like this back when the game came out. The detail is surprisingly high on the characters themselves, the towns are somewhat large and many of the buildings can be entered. Most spells and attacks have their own cinematics/animations to make them different from the previous level which is nice. The bosses were also well done and geniunely nightmare fuel.

[Sound - good]: The music is very 90s which I don't hate. The hymns were sung beautifully and conveyed sadness or hope prefectly. I don't know who did the vocals for them but props to whoever it was. The sound affects fit for the most part but the sounds for everyone's footsteps seemed really odd. I won't comment on the English voice acting since I switched it to Japanese immediately but everyone's voices fit well. Not every conversation had the voice audio, it was mostly saved for cinematics and important cutscenes which worked well... other than the considerable de-syncing haflway through the game.

[Difficulty - bad]: This game was easy, given that I played on normal, but even on hard I've heard it doesn't go up by much. There are a few fights that are somewhat hard but once you've figured out the strategy they fall over pretty easily. One of the hardest fights isn't even a boss fight. It's enemies called Devils that can 1-shot your party if you let them cast a certain spell and you get to fight 3 at a time. The other hard parts of the game weren't fights at all, they were mini-games(especially the arm wrestling one). Although really, no oldschool JRPG is complete without ridiculous mini-games to get some nice items. At least they aren't game-breakingly powerful items that you absolutely must get to complete the game.

[Combat - excellent]: This is where Grandia II shines brightest. It may be turn-based but the way they've designed it makes it feel very fast paced. It's also simple to learn (you can skip the tutorials completely) but takes some planning to master. There's a lot of different kinds of equipment and the spells in this game come from Eggs which you have to equip. The best part about this is that as you gain more Eggs you can then swap them in the middle of battle should you need more offensive or defensive spells. Along with equipment and Eggs you also get skill books that grant various bonuses to help offense, defense or magic stat setups. You have a turn order bar which is crucial to watch so you can decide what action you should take. You have a lot of options to choose from when it comes to your turn: 
Choose to hold your ground and defend which will lessen the time to reach your next turn.
Move your character's position to evade incoming attacks.
Use critical melee attacks to cancel the enemy's attacks.
Combo melee attacks to counter the enemy mid-attack to do bonus damage.
Cast magic for elemental damage bonuses, healing, support, attack cancelling or debuffing.
Use special skills to do tons of damage, cancel attacks, buffing or healing your allies.
Use items or swap equipment/Eggs mid-fight.
Most battles will have you and the enemies running around constantly which you should try to exploit as much as possible.

[Length - good]: It honestly didn't feel very long but even taking away idle time and optional grinding, it still comes in at about 50 hours which is pretty good for the pacing.

[Replayability - average]: There isn't a whole lot of incentive to play it over again since you see pretty much everything the game has to offer the first time through. Even the achievements aren't that difficult to get and are probably very doable in just one run. The charm and combat makes the game worth playing multiple times though.

[Bugs - average]: There was a bug that was caused by using the tutorials at the start of the game but as I played, that one was mentioned as being fixed. There also seems to be issues with using controllers with the game sometimes and the sensitivity of the controller can hinder you during the mini-games. I had one crash during my playthrough but I couldn't reproduce it so who knows if it's a problem with the game or something else. I also noticed that the dialogue would stutter to a snail's pace or zip by sometimes, making it hard to read. My other peeves are mentioned at the top but for the most part the issues with the game were tolerable for me.
